he Board of Cambian announces that, following receipt of its September management accounts and the re-forecast for the remainder of the year, it believes that Underlying EBITDA for the year to 31 December 2015 will be not less than £54m, representing growth of 7.5% on the prior year, and Adjusted EBITDA for the year to 31 December 2015 will be not less than £49m; (2014 £48.4m). These numbers represent a shortfall to previous expectations.
The reasons for this shortfall are a significant increase in organic investment in new places, with growth capital expenditure of over £50m expected in the year, which has resulted in increased development losses, and in addition the impact of staff vacancies which has reduced the number of admissions in our Schools and Children's Services.

11:17 am
PM

The ECB will be the market’s key focus today. We do not expect the ECB to extend the scope and size of its asset purchase program at this meeting. However, we expect the EBC to reiterate its willingness, ability, and readiness to act given the weak inflation outlook and deteriorating growth environment. We look for more monetary easing before year-end, which should put further downward pressure on the EUR in the coming quarters (Full Story). Our view should be supported by further USD strength, as monetary policy expectations in the US seem too benign compared with the healthy dynamics of internal demand in the US. The EUR was little changed during Asia trading, ahead of the ECB meeting. Treasuries followed euro area bonds higher on expectations of more QE in December.

11:19 am
PM

This morning SIG has released an unscheduled trading update indicating that it will deliver
FY15 profit before tax within a range of £85-90m which compares to Goodbody forecasts of
£103m and consensus for £101m. This implies a H215 PBT decline of 10-20% versus -6% in
H115.
Management notes that the improving lfl sales tends witnessed in Europe have not continued
with deterioration particularly in France most notable in September while October remains
difficult. In addition, demand in the UK rmi market has been lower than expected. This has
impacted gross margins which are now expected to be broadly flat yoy (Goodbody forecast
+c20bps for FY and were up 20bps in H115) with savings from procurement being offset by
competitive pressures and adverse volume effects.

PM

Despite the challenging backdrop management continues to be encouraged at the scope for
self-help and has announced £20m savings following the supply chain review in addition to
savings from the procurement initiatives.
This is a disappointing update from SIG which will caste further uncertainty over
the ability of the group to drive margins on despite further cost savings announced
this morning. We will expect to revise our forecasts down by 15-20% with SIG’s
share price likely to come under severe pressure as a result.

PM

Robert Eason the analyst there

11:21 am
PM

(WIWY -- apols. Can you screenshot?)

PM

And Panmure

PM

Over the last few weeks the mood music in the UK and European construction
markets has deteriorated, with growth trends materially softening. This has
resulted in SIG’s group like-for-likes reducing from +2.8% (1H15) to negative
0.9% (3Q15). The tough environment has also impacted on gross margins. As a
consequence, we are reducing our FY15 PBT estimates to £85.3m (an 18%
downgrade). However, today’s update is not all doom and gloom. Management
has confirmed they are targeting cost efficiencies of at least £20m from phase
two of the self-help initiatives (phase one £30m). Whilst this is unlikely to offset
the impact on investor sentiment it highlights the on-going operational
improvements to the business.

11:21 am
PM

This morning SIG has provided an update to the market, indicating that recent trading
has underperformed expectations in both the UK and on the Continent. Like for like
sales growth in the UK and Ireland have fallen from +2.8% during 1H15 to +0.4%
during 3Q15. In Europe LFL have fallen from -1.5% (1H15) to -2.3% (3Q15). Given the
softer comps in Europe it had been expected to see an improving trend but the trend
(for the moment) has gone the other way. Some of this slowdown reflects industry
volumes (particularly in UK RMI) and in France (generally) but it also reflects
competitive pricing by Travis Perkins in the UK.
 Given recent macro data this slowdown at SIG is not a massive surprise. For example,
Eurostat showed that in August the European construction sector declined 5%, with
France and UK being hit particularly hard. However, since SIG distributes products
used later in the construction lifecycle this slowdown is only (materially) coming
through now.
 Given the tough trading environment, gross margins have been impacted. This partly
reflects the pricing environment and partly reflects lower rebates from suppliers
(given the lower volumes passing through).

PM

So I guess we need to go into DPL mode

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 85.15, up 4 (+4.93%), High: 85.30, Low: 82.70, Volume: 2.74m
PM

Let me get RBC to explain

11:40 am
PM

Richard Chamberlain

PM

Debenhams has reported better than expected FY results with headline PBT of £113.5mn compared to our and consensus expectations of £112mn, EPS of 7.6p compared to our 7.4p estimate and DPS of 3.4p in line with our 3.4p forecast. FY16 guidance is better than expected in terms of gross margin, depreciation and interest charges and the outlook statement is encouraging. CEO Michael Sharp has announced plans to step down in 2016 after 5 years as Debenhams' CEO but will help with the search for a successor which should ensure a smooth handover. We maintain our Outperform rating as we think Debenhams is an inexpensive share with renewed operational momentum.

PM

For FY16 Debenhams is looking for a gross margin increase of 0-50-bps compared to our +10bps estimate, depreciation of £110mn compared to our £112mn forecast and interest charges of £18-20mn compared to our £20mn estimate. Debenhams states that it has made an encouraging start to the new financial year and is in good shape for the key Christmas trading period.

In our Sept 1 report we upgraded Debenhams to Outperform as we thought the share price was pricing in no growth, yet Debenhams has just reported its first full-year PBT growth in 4 years, and we expect it to make further progress in the year ahead. Debenhams trades at a c.32% P/E discount to the sector compared to 25-30% historically and offers a c.10% FCF yield and 4% dividend yield.

11:41 am
PM

Structural pressures but also advantages- in our recent report we pointed to several structural pressures facing department stores such as Debenhams, in particular: 1) Fairly low sales densities, 2) Long-term rent contracts reflecting its anchor tenant status, and 3) High promotional activity although this is not getting worse. However we think Debenhams has several structural advantages too such as: 1) High exposure to the growing Health & Beauty category, 2) Market leader in occasionwear, 3) Close to 100% brand recognition in the UK, and 4) The ability to differentiate, for instance with its Designers at Debenhams ranges.

PM

Survey work indicates range advantage and well regarded multi-channel offer - our consumer survey of 1,000 people in the UK suggests that

Debenhams has a range advantage over other softlines retailers, coming second only to Asos. Debenhams also comes top quartile for its online offer, more specifically in terms of delivery options, click & collect, online payment options and for its mobile/tablet offer. It is also extending the time for online next day delivery from 7pm to 9pm. This gives us confidence that Debenhams can continue to grow its constant currency LFL sales and continue to gain market share in apparel.

PM

Market leader in occasionwear? Always wondered what Debs was for.

11:42 am
PM

Improved offer through space optimisation and online enhancements - Debenhams is optimising around 1 million square feet of space by adding to its Designers offer for example, it has introduced a range by Savannah Miller in 65 stores, rolling out own bought brands such as Principles and Hammond, expanding its Beauty offer, trialling several concession brands such as Monsoon, Only, Jack & Jones and Sports Direct and enhancing its cafe and food brands, e.g. with Costa Coffee. This should enable it to achieve a better return from previously unproductive space. It is also improving its online offer, e.g.by extending order cut off times for next day or evening delivery, in time for peak trading this year.

PM

So richard is very much a buyer at RBC

11:46 am
PM

It's actually growing

PM

revenue wise

PM

LADBROKES^ (LAD, Hold at 102p) - Q3 update - As expected operating profit fell sharply (from £33m to £14m) reflecting tough World Cup comps and regulatory headwinds. Encouragingly, the group reported underlying revenue growth, albeit the cost of delivering this growth and regulatory pressures means it wasn't enough to drive profit growth. In retail, amounts wagered were up 1.8% (after several quarters of declines) and machine gross win per shop up 8.6%. In online sportsbook amounts wagered were up strongly, whilst actives and gaming revenue saw double digit growth. Despite this growth, the win margin disappointed even though football was said to be strong. Overall, operating costs were in line.

Q3 was said to be in line with management expectations suggesting the group remains on track for c£70m of operating profit for the full year (c4p of earnings) - implying Q4 profits consistent with the third quarter.

We see the trends on amounts wagered as encouraging although the margin continues to frustrate. We therefore retain a HOLD stance, although noting that the current price appears to assume little chance of the Coral merger completing, which may be overly pessimistic.

11:47 am
PM

that's Greg Johnson at Shore

PM

And Panmure...

PM

Ladbrokes has reported a Q3 trading update for the period to the end of
September, with trading poor but in line with expectations. Good football
results in the quarter has been offset by poor horse racing results, whilst tough
comparatives and UK POC have also impacted, resulting in a 57% decline in
group EBIT to £14.3m. Following today’s update we retain our 2015 estimates
and retain our Hold recommendation, price target 110p.

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 952.00, down 46.5 (-4.66%), High: 976.00, Low: 947.50, Volume: 3.28m
undefined
11:51 am
PM

But I wil do some Anglo American

PM

Well, I will let RBC do some AAL

PM

A mixed bag of production which will likely be overshadowed by production cuts in iron ore, diamonds and copper (previously guided).

11:52 am
PM

Iron ore beat, guidance cut: Kumba production of 11.4mt was a beat vs. RBC at 10.6mt driven by better performance from Sishen and a resurgence in production from Kolomela. Anglo has trimmed Kumba production guidance by 1mt to ~43mt, with weaker production expected from Sishen (31mt vs. 33mt previously) as waste mining picks up; this is offset partially by a 1mt increase to guidance for Kolomela (this will see an increase in waste mining). Minas Rio continues its ramp up with production of 2.9mt, although water issues in the quarter drove a miss vs. our 4mt estimate and Anglo has revised down its Minas Rio FY15 production guidance to 10mt from 11-14mt.

PM

Copper misses: Copper production of 171kt was a miss vs. RBC at 191kt driven by a mixture of weaker throughput at Los Bronces due to water constraints (which have now abated) and weaker production vs. our forecasts from the AA Norte assets which were sold in the quarter. Production guidance has been reduced to 680-710kt (from 720-750kt) to reflect the sale of the AA Norte assets (~37kt) and a ~3kt cut at Collahuasi as oxide production is curtailed.

PM

Export met up: Australian export met production of 5.5mt was a beat vs. RBC at 5.2mt due to stronger performance from Capcoal, while thermal export lagged our 1.9mt forecast at 1.4mt as Drayton nears the end of its life, and thermal domestic production of 1.8mt was lower than our 2.2mt forecast. Production guidance is unchanged at 20-21mt.
Thermal weaker: SA export thermal production of 4.9mt was in line vs. RBC; however, Eskom thermal production lagged our 7.7mt forecast at 6.8mt due to weaker demand, and non-Eskom thermal production of 1.7mt was a touch below our 1.8mt forecast. Cerrejon produced 2.5mt, vs. RBC at 3mt. Production guidance for export thermal is unchanged at 28-30mt.

11:53 am
PM

Platinum broadly in line: Refined platinum production of 611koz was in line vs. RBC at 618koz, while refined palladium production of 391koz was in line with our 389koz; refined rhodium lagged our 87koz forecast at 78koz. Production guidance is unchanged at 2.3-2.4moz.

PM

Diamonds miss: Diamonds continues its challenging year with production of 6mct missing our 7.4mct forecast driven by the bringing forward of planned maintenance at Jwaneng and Orapa due to weaker market conditions. Production guidance has been revised down to 29mct from ~29-31mct.
Nickel upside: Nickel production of 6.8kt slightly lagged our 7.2kt forecast, although progress at Barro Alto continues ahead of schedule and budget. FY15 guidance raised to 28-30kt (from 25-30kt).

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 597.80, down 6.8 (-1.12%), High: 598.80, Low: 577.60, Volume: 3.59m
